metadata.title: RETRACTED: Enantioselective epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins by Jacobsen's catalyst immobilized on amino-modified ZnPS-PVPA

A recyclable chiral Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst immobilized on ZnPSâ€�PVPA on diamines gave high catalytic activity (conversion > 99%, ee > 99%) in the asymmetric epoxidations of unfunctionâ€� alized olefins. The synergistic effect of the support ZnPSâ€�PVPA and the linkage as well as chiral salen Mn center contributed to the chirality of the product. The stability (recycled nine times) and the ease of use in large scale reactions (200 times scale) indicated a catalyst useful for industrial use. Keywords: Chiral salen Mn(III) Aryldiamine Alkyldiamine Asymmetric epoxidation of olefins Zinc poly (styreneâ€�phenylâ€� vinylphosphonate)â€�phosphate Â Â 1. Introduction High atomic efficiency for waste free processes is an imâ€� portant goal in asymmetric catalysis in the chirality economy [1,2]. High enantioselectivity has been achieved with homogeâ€� neous catalysts, but their separation, recovery, and reuse reâ€� main arduous [3â€“7]. Clearly, heterogeneous catalysts with high enantioselectivity would be an important development for apâ€� plications in industrial and high throughput organic chemistry [8â€“10]. The catalytic epoxidation of olefins is a subject of growing interest in the production of chemicals and fine chemicals beâ€� cause epoxides are the key starting materials for a wide variety of products [11,12]. Much effort has been made to develop new active and selective epoxidation catalysts for the processes with the aim to eliminate byproducts. Jacobsen epoxidation [13] has emerged as a powerful method for the asymmetric oxidation of unfunctionalized olefins. It is catalyzed by strucâ€� turally simple Mn(III)â€�salen complexes and has been optimized in terms of the catalyst structure and choice of stoichiometric oxidants and other additives. Recently, various methods have been employed to heterogenize Mnâ€�salen complexes on naâ€� noporous materials [14â€“24]. We have worked to immobilize Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst on a seâ€� * Corresponding author. DOI: 10.1016/S1872â€�2067(16)62489â€�0 | http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/18722067 | Chin. J. Catal., Vol. 37, No. 9, September 2016 RE TR AC TE D 1540 Jing Huang et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis 37 (2016) 1539â€“1548 ries of hybrid materials, such as zirconium oliâ€� gostyrenylphosphonateâ€�phosphate (ZSPP) and zirconium poly (styreneâ€�phenylvinylphosphonate)â€�phosphate (ZPSâ€�PVPA) and zinc poly(styreneâ€�phenylvinylphosphonate)â€�phosphate (ZnPSâ€� PVPA) and calcium poly(styreneâ€�phenylvinylphosâ€� phoâ€� nate)â€�phosphate (CaPSâ€�PVPA). The heterogeneous chiral salen Mn(III) catalysts showed superior performance in the asymâ€� metric epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins[25â€“32]. We have the general goals of designing and synthesizing new chiral catalysts in an efficient and economical manner on a large scale. In this work, we used Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst anchored on aminoâ€�modified ZnPSâ€�PVPA for the asymmetric epoxidaâ€� tions of unfunctionalized olefins. To investigate the effects of the diamines as the linkers on the morphology and disposition of the catalysts, we introduced alkyl diamines and aryl diaâ€� mines into the catalysts. The immediate goals of our studies were to evaluate the effect of a distribution of chiral ligands on the enantioselectivity of alkene epoxidation and to determine the extent to which the catalyst can be recycled for repeated use as well as to investigate the catalysts in large scale reacâ€� tions. The results of these efforts are described here. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials and instruments All chemicals and reagents were analytical grade and used as received. All solvents were further purified before use. The chiral salen ligand and chiral homogeneous catalyst salen Mn(III) were synthesized according to standard literature proâ€� cedures [33], and were identified by the analysis and compariâ€� son of the IR spectra with the literature [34]. FTâ€�IR spectra were recorded using KBr pellets and a Bruker RFS100/S spectrophotometer (USA). The diffuse reflectance UVâ€�Vis spectra of the solid samples were recorded on a specâ€� trophotometer with an integrating sphere using BaSO4 as standard. 1H NMR and 31P NMR were performed on an AVâ€�300 NMR instrument at ambient temperature at 300 and 121 MHz, respectively. All of the chemical shifts were reported downfield in ppm relative to the hydrogen and phosphorus resonance of TMS and 85% H3PO4, respectively. Number and weight average molecular weights (Mn and Mw) and polydispersity (Mw/Mn) were estimated using a Waters1515 gel permeation chromatoâ€� graph (GPC; against polystyrene standards) using THF as eluâ€� ent (1.0 mL/min) at 35 Â°C. Xâ€�ray photoelectron spectrum was recorded on ESCALab 250 instrument. The interlayer spacings were obtained using a DXâ€�1000 automated Xâ€�ray power difâ€� fractometer, using Cu KÎ± radiation and an internal silicon powâ€� der standard with all samples. The patterns were measured between 3.00Â° and 80.00Â° with a step size of 0.02Â°/min. The Xâ€�ray tube settings were 36 kV and 20 mA. C, H and N eleâ€� mental analysis was obtained using an EATM 1112 automatic elemental analyzer instrument (Thermo, USA). TG analyses were performed on an SBTQ600 thermal analyzer (USA) with the heating rate of 20 Â°C/min from 25 to 1000 Â°C under flowing N2 (100 mL/min). The Mn contents of the catalysts were deâ€� termined by a TASâ€�986G (Pgeneral, China) atomic absorption spectroscopy. SEM was performed on a KYKYâ€�EM 3200 (KYKY, China) microscope. TEM was obtained on a TECNAI10 (PHILIPS, Holland) apparatus. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured at â€“196 Â°C on a 3Hâ€�2000I (Huihaihong, China) volumetric adsorption analyzer with the BET method. The raâ€� cemic epoxides were prepared by the epoxidation of the corâ€� responding olefins by 3â€�chloroperbenzoic acid in CH2Cl2 and confirmed by NMR (Bruker AVâ€�300). Gas chromatography (GC) was calibrated with the samples of nâ€�nonane, olefins and the corresponding racemic epoxides. The conversion (with nâ€�nonane as internal standard) and ee value were obtained by GC with a Shimadzu GC2010 (Japan) instrument equipped with a chiral column (HP19091Gâ€�B213, 30 m Ã— 30 m Ã— 0.32 mm Ã— 0.25 Î¼m) and FID detector using injector 230 Â°C, detector 230 Â°C. Ultrapure nitrogen was used as the carrier (rate 34 mL/min) with a carrier pressure of 39.1 kPa and the injection port temperature was set at 230 Â°C. 2.2. Asymmetric epoxidation 2.5.1. Using mâ€�CPBA as oxidant For mâ€�CPBA/NMO, the activity of the prepared catalysts was tested with alkene (1 mmol), nâ€�nonane (internal standard, 1 mmol), NMO (5 mmol), homogeneous (5 mol%) or heterogeâ€� neous salen Mn(III) catalysts (5 mol%) and mâ€�CPBA (2 mmol) for the epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins in CH2Cl2. After the reaction, Na2CO3 (2 mL, 1.0 mol/L) was added to quench the reaction. 2.5.2. Using NaIO4 as oxidant For the NaIO4/imidazole system, the reaction was carried out with alkene (1 mmol), NaIO4 (2 mmol) and the catalyst (5 mol%) in a mixture of acetonitrile : water = 2:1. 2.6. Reusability of the catalyst In a typical recycling test, an equal volume of hexane was added to the mixture after the reaction. Subsequently, the orâ€� ganic phase was separated, followed by washing and drying. The recovered catalyst was weighed and reused in the next run. In all runs, the same proportion of substrateâ€�toâ€�catalyst and solventâ€�toâ€�catalyst was retained. 2.7. General procedure for the large scale asymmetric epoxidation reaction A solution of catalyst 4d (2.5 mmol), nâ€�nonane (50 mmol) and ï�¡â€�methylstyrene (50 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (150 mL) at ï€­40 Â°C was stirred for 30 min. Then, mâ€�CPBA (100 mmol) was added to the solution step by step. After Na2CO3 (100 mL, 1.0 mol/L) was added to quench the reaction, the organic layer was dried over sodium sulfate. The conversions and ee values of the epoxide were determined by GC. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Characterizations of the heterogeneous chiral catalysts 3.1.1. IR spectroscopy and UVâ€�Vis spectroscopy Catalysts 4(aâ€“g) and Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst have the same band at 1638 cmâˆ’1 (Fig. 1) due to the vibration of the imine group. The azomethene (C=N) stretching band was in the vicinity of 1617 cmâˆ’1 for Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst and the supported catalysts. The band at 3408 cmâˆ’1 was observed for the catalysts, which was assigned to the stretching vibration of Nâ€“H groups. The stretching vibration at 1030 cmâˆ’1 which was assigned to the vibrations of the phosphonate and phosphate in the support ZnPSâ€�PVPA was obviously weakened by the electronic strucâ€� ture changes of the hostâ€�guest interaction. The common promâ€� inent bands at 1145, 1089, and 986 cmâˆ’1 were assigned to the Râ€�PO32ï€­ phosphonate stretching vibrations. The phosphonate and phosphate stretching vibrations contributed to the adsorpâ€� tion at 1201, 1144, and 1077 cmâˆ’1. In the UVâ€�Vis spectra (Fig. 2), the band at 335 nm can be atâ€� tributed to the charge transfer transition of the salen ligand. The band at 433 nm was due to the ligandâ€�toâ€�metal charge transfer transition. The band at 510 nm was assigned to the dâ€“d transition of salen Mn(III) complex. Thermal gravimetric analysis and powder XRD For catalyst 4b (Fig. 3(a)), the initial mass loss was 3.38% below 200 Â°C due to the loss of surfaceâ€�bound and intercalated water. Subsequently, the organic moieties decomposed with 69.32% mass loss in the temperature range of 200â€“850 Â°C. For catalyst 4g (Fig. 3(b)), a similar mass loss procedure occurred with an initial 3.5% mass loss below 180 Â°C and then 56.8% mass loss for the decomposition of the organic moieties in the range of 180â€“700 Â°C. Notably, both catalysts 4b and 4g still maintained superior stability below 180 Â°C, which indicated that the heterogeneous catalysts can be utilized in asymmetric epoxidation. Compared with ZnPSâ€�PVPA (Fig. 4), many crystalline peaks have disappeared or were diminished for catalysts 4b and 4g upon the immobilization of Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst. For catalyst 4b, the intensity of the peaks at 2.02Â°, 25.4Â° and 42.16Â° decreased with a small shift toward lower 2Î¸ values, which confirmed that the mesoporous structure of the parent support remained inâ€� tact after the modification with aryl diamine. Some peaks in the XRD pattern of the catalyst were relatively reinforced as the other peaks weakened. A similar phenomenon occurred with catalyst 4g. In addition, the interlayer distance of catalyst 4b (4.33 Â± 0.02 nm) was nearly twice that of ZnPSâ€�PVPA (2.1 Â± 0.13 nm) owing to the introduction of Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst on the pâ€�phenylenediamine that made the zinc layer stretch. For cataâ€� lyst 4g, the interlayer distance (0.237 Â± 0.01 nm) was instead narrower than that of ZnPSâ€�PVPA (2.1 Â± 0.13 nm) by virtue of Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst being anchored on ZnPSâ€�PVPA through 1,6â€�diaminohexane. In the configuration of catalysts 4b and 4g, the difference lies in the rigid linker for 4b and the flexible linker for 4g. In essence, the mode of the immobilization of Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst and the corresponding microenvironment contributed to the phenomenon. 3.1.3. N2 adsorption isotherm As described in Fig. 5(a), catalyst 4b showed a distribution of pore size of 2â€“8 nm and a characteristic Type V isotherm. For catalyst 4g (Fig. 5(b)), the N2 adsorption isotherm was characâ€� teristically Type V with a distinct hysteresis loop (Type H1). The pore diameters varied from 1 to 18 nm, and a small amount below 2 nm and a few over 50 nm in diameter. The textural parameters calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms and Mn content of the immobilized catalysts were shown in Table 1. In contrast, upon the immobilization of chiral salen Mn(III) onto ZnPSâ€�PVPA, decreases were seen in the BET surâ€� face area (3b and 4b, from 42.5 to 31.66 m2/g), pore volume (3b and 4b, from 0.242 to 0.0543 cm3/g) and pore diameter (3b and 4b, from 11.39 to 1.56 nm). For catalyst 4g, owing to the immobilization of Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst, the textural parameâ€� ters similarly showed a decrease in BET surface area (2 and 4g, from 36.9 to 28.02 m2/g), pore volume (2 and 4g, from 0.1882 to 0.04442 cm3/g) and pore diameter (2 and 4g, from 10.21 to 0.61 nm). From these facts, it can be deduced that two forms of the immobilization of Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst existed: inner type and outer type. 3.1.4. Analysis of surface morphology From the SEM photographs (Fig. 6), catalysts 4b and 4g have a similar loose amorphous configuration, which conâ€� firmed that the morphology of the catalysts did not depend on the linker. Moreover, the morphology of 4b and 4g was much transformed versus ZnPSâ€�PVPA (smooth anomalous structure), which was different from most of the results reported [25â€“27] such as the immobilized chiral salen Mn(III) on ZPSâ€�PVPA. Simâ€� ultaneously, many small caves and channels with irregular shapes also were present. The amorphous morphology and porous structure of the catalysts together would increase the surface area (ZnPSâ€�PVPA, 4b, and 4g; 4.9, 31.66 and 28.02 m2/g) and helped substrates onto the catalytic active sites. As described in Fig. 7, both the catalysts 4b and 4g showed a loose configuration. RE TR AC TE D Jing Huang et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis 37 (2016) 1539â€“1548 1545 existed, which confirmed that the linkers hardly had an effect on the morphology. Notably, the TEM images of catalysts 4b and 4g were changed compared to that of ZnPSâ€�PVPA which manifested a spheroid structure. Therefore, the special configâ€� uration of the catalysts helped the substrates get to the internal catalytic active sites easily and provided enough space for the asymmetric epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins. 3.2. Catalytic epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins 3.2.1. Effect of different oxidants 3.2.1.1. Oxidation system of mâ€�CPBA/NMO To investigate the control of the chirality of the product, the support ZnPSâ€�PVPA and 3b as well as homogeneous catalyst 6a were utilized to epoxidize indene (Table 2). Low olefin enanâ€� tioâ€�excesses were obtained (ee = 0% in entry 17 and ee = 22.6% in entry 6), which indicated that both ZnPSâ€�PVPA and the support 3b were stereochemically inactive for the epoxidaâ€� tion of olefins. Meanwhile, the ee values increased from 54% to 83.7% (Jacobsenâ€™s and 6a, entry 1 and entry 8) due to the modâ€� ification of pâ€�phenylenediamine and further increased to >99% (6a vs 4b, entry 8 vs entry 3) upon the immobilizing on ZnPSâ€�PVPA. In the asymmetric epoxidation of Î±â€�methylstyrene and styrene, similar observations were also taken. Based on these results, it was deduced that for the catalysts 4(aâ€“c), a synergistic effect of the support ZnPSâ€�PVPA, linkage aryl diaâ€� mine and chiral salen Mn center contributed to the chirality of the products. For catalysts 4(dâ€“g), a similar synergism affected the enanâ€� tioselectivity, which was also unrelated to the linkers. Upon the functionalization of alkyl diamine and immobilization, the ee values increased from 54% to 86.7% (entry 1 vs entry 15) and further up to 98% (entry 12). 3.2.1.2. The conversion and the ee value were determined by GC with chiral capillary columns HP19 091Gâ€�B213, 30 m Ã— 0.32 mm Ã— 0.25 Î¼m. b Reactions conditions: alkene (1 mmol), NaIO4 (2 mmol), catalyst (0.03 mmol), CH3CN/H2O (10 mL/5 mL). c Turnover frequency calculated by [product]/[catalyst] Ã— time. RE TR AC TE D 1546 Jing Huang et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis 37 (2016) 1539â€“1548 For catalysts 4(aâ€“c), the catalytic activities were comparaâ€� ble to the homogeneous catalyst 6a and Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst (ee, >99% vs >99% vs 69%; entries 19â€“21 vs entry 23 vs entry 18). The conversion and enantioselectivity of catalyst 4b exceeded 95%, even >99%. From catalysts 4(dâ€“g), the catalytic disposiâ€� tions remained superior to Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst and the homogâ€� enous catalyst 6b (ee, 4(dâ€“g) vs Jacobsenâ€™s vs 6b; >99% vs 69% vs 82%, entries 25â€“28 vs entry 18 vs entry 30). Apart from this, the ee values varied from 69% (Jacobsenâ€™s, entry 18) to 82% (6b, entry 30) through the modification of 1,6â€�hexanediamine, followed by increasing to >99% (4g, entry 28) upon the immobilization of catalyst 6b on ZnPSâ€�PVPA. That is, the combined effects of ZnPSâ€�PVPA and the linker as well as chiral ligand contributed to the superior activity in NaIO4/imidazole. 3.2.2. Effect of the linkage According to mâ€�CPBA/NMO, catalyst 4b showed higher acâ€� tivity than catalyst 4a in the asymmetric epoxidation of indene (conversion ï€¾99% vs 80.5%; ee, ï€¾99% vs 94.5%; entries 3 and 2). This was due to the high symmetry of rigid pâ€� phenylenediâ€� amine which decreased the steric obstacles. For catalyst 4c, a lower activity (conversion 86.4% vs ï€¾99%; ee, 92.3% vs ï€¾99%; entries 3 and 4) was displayed due to the bulkier linker benziâ€� dine making the substrates approach the catalyst with diffiâ€� cultly. For catalysts 4(dâ€“g), the catalytic activities increased with the length of the linkage in mâ€�CPBA/NMO (entries 9â€“12). For instance, the ee values increased from 81% to 98%, conâ€� version from 80% to >99% with the increase of carbon number of the alkyl diamine in the asymmetric epoxidation of indene, which was reported by Liâ€™s group [17] and our group [29]. The phenomenon can be interpreted as that the augmentation of the linkage was in favour of the heterogeneous salen Mn(III) complexes approaching the active intermediates of salen Mn(V) or their transition states more easily. For NaIO4/imidazole, neither the rigid aryl diamine nor the increase of the flexible chain length have effects on the catalytic activity. For example, the conversion and enantioselectivity exceed 99% (entries 19â€“21 and 25â€“28), which remained unâ€� changed with the different linkers. This could be due to the superior oxidation of NaIO4 so that the effect of the linkers on the catalytic ability can be neglected. 3.2.3. Effect of the axial ligand Notably, high catalytic activities were obtained with the heterogeneous catalyst 4b (conversion >99% vs 7.8%; ee, >99% vs 4.5%; entries 3 and 5) and the homogeneous catalyst 6a (conversion 98.7% vs 91.2%; ee, 83.7% vs 25.5%; entries 7 and 8) in the absence of the additive NMO which is commonly required to improve the catalytic activity. This was in contrast to most literature reports [36]. Several factors contributed to this. First, the spatial orientation of the rigid aryl diamine can play the role of the Nâ€�oxide ligand (NMO). At the same time, the additives were generally axial ligands on the transition metal catalyst, which made the catalyst active either toward oxidation or toward reactivity with the olefin. When the Nâ€�oxide ligand (NMO) was added, a steric hindrance was brought about, and the optimal geometric configuration of the reactive intermediâ€� ate salen Mn(V)=O was altered. The steric hindrance would prevent the olefins from approaching salen Mn (V)=O so that lower ee values were generated. However, the catalytic activity of catalyst 4g (conversion >99% vs 51%; ee, 98% vs 8%; enâ€� tries 12 and 13) and the homogeneous catalyst 6b (conversion 89% vs 76%; ee, 86.7% vs 82.5%; entries 15 and 16) obviously increased with the addition of NMO in the epoxidation of inâ€� dene, which was in agreement with most papers [25â€“27]. In summary, superior activity for the catalysts with rigid aryl diâ€� amines in the absence of NMO and for the catalysts with flexible alkyl diamines in the presence of NMO was observed. For NaIO4/imidazole, the superior catalytic activity of cataâ€� lysts 4b and 4g as well as the homogeneous catalyst 6a was still be maintained with the addition of imidazole and without (conversion up to 99%; ee%, up to 99%; entry 20 vs entry 22, entry 23 vs entry 24, entry 28 vs entry 29). For the homogeneâ€� ous catalyst 6b, the catalytic activity increased a little in the presence of imidazole (conversion 86% vs 83%; ee, 82% vs 79%; entry 30 vs entry 31). That was, the axial ligand imidazole had a subtle impact on the catalytic activity. The catalytic tests indicated excellent catalytic activities (conversion 97%; ee, >99%) in the absence of the axial ligand imidazole and lower activities (conversion 70%; ee, 88%) [37] with the addition of imidazole. Therefore, the additive imidazole played different roles in different catalyst systems. 3.3. Reusability of the catalysts The reusability of a heterogeneous catalyst was of great importance from synthetic and economical points of view. Hoâ€� mogeneous catalysts usually cannot be recovered even once. However, supported catalysts 4(aâ€“g) could be filtered and reâ€� used several times with the retention of their activity. As shown in Fig. 8, catalysts 4b and 4g maintained favouraâ€� ble activities after recycling nine times (conversion 88% vs 89%; ee, 86.1% vs 91%; 4b and 4g). The effective separating of the chiral salen Mn(III) complexes by the solid support ZnPSâ€�PVPA could avoid the generation of the inactive Î¼â€�oxoâ€�Mn(IV) species and ultimately contributed to the superiâ€� or stability of the catalyst. The decrease of the yield was atâ€� tributed to the decomposition of the chiral Mn(III) salen comâ€� plex under epoxidative conditions [38] and the loss of hyperâ€� fine granules of the heterogeneous chiral Mn(III) salen catalyst. After recycling nine times, the Mn content of the catalysts 4b and 4g decreased (4b, 0.46 mmol/g; 4g, 0.45 mmol/g) comâ€� pared with the fresh catalyst (4b, 0.72 mmol/g; 4g, 0.73 mmol/g). In the FTâ€�IR spectra of the recovered catalyst 4b (Fig. 9), the characteristic bands at 2954, 2864 and 1630 cmâˆ’1 disâ€� appeared or were weakened after recycling ten times, which indicated that the active sites of the salen Mn(III) complex and the support ZnPSâ€�PVPA were partly destroyed under the acid reaction conditions. 3.4. Large scale asymmetric epoxidation reaction We further carried out different scales of large scale asymâ€� RE TR AC TE D Jing Huang et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis 37 (2016) 1539â€“1548 1547 metric epoxidation reactions with ï�¡â€�methylstyrene as subâ€� strate and mâ€�CPBA as oxidant. The same catalyst loading of 5 mol% as that used in the experimental scale was employed. The large scale experiments could be facilely performed using the same procedure as the experimental scale reactions. The catalytic activities were shown in Fig. 10. Delightfully, the supeâ€� rior catalytic performance could still be maintained for the large scale reactions even when the scale was 200 times that of the experimental scale. 4. Conclusions The epoxidation catalyst, Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst, anchored on ZnPSâ€�PVPA gave good to excellent chemical yields and enantiâ€� oselectivity in the asymmetric epoxidation of unfunctionalized alkenes. The heterogeneous catalyst retained its high atom efficiency after recycling nine times and could perform effecâ€� tively on a large scale. The additives played different roles in different oxidation systems. However, the asymmetric inducâ€� tion was low in some cases. Further optimization and investiâ€� gation of the scope and mechanisms of supported Jacobsenâ€™s catalyst for asymmetric epoxidation of alkenes are ongoing in our laboratory. References [1] H. C.
